name: Florida Phoenix
title: The year of the university president and lessons learned in accounting
description: Politics around leadership of the state’s higher learning institutions and funding of younger students’ schooling dominated the public education field during 2025. The state’s education budget is the mechanism that keeps schools paid — public and (some) private. Until it doesn’t. A state audit revealed last month a problem public and private schools were exp[...]
text:
The Florida Historic Capitol dome. (Photo by Jay Waagmeester/Florida Phoenix)Politics around leadership of the state’s higher learning institutions and funding of younger students’ schooling dominated the public education field during 2025.
Voucher mess up
The state’s education budget is the mechanism that keeps schools paid — public and (some) private. Until it doesn’t.
A state audit revealed last month a problem public and private schools were experiencing long before the issue surfaced in the Legislature: Money for the state’s school voucher system was not following the student as intended.
‘Funding did not follow the child’: State audit displays school choice woes

Lawmakers head into 2026 in search of a solution, and the Senate has already advanced its proposal.
The damage done by lax accounting practices in the previous school year left schools short $47 million.
Taxpayers are projected to spend more than $4 billion on school vouchers next year, making the need to refine the statutes all the more pressing.
University presidents
The metaphorical clubhouse for Florida’s state university presidents experienced a major shift in membership in the last few years, particularly in 2025. 
As outlined in a piece about Florida State University President Richard McCullough, a number of university president jobs have been taken over by friends of the governor.
The University of Florida named its second consecutive interim president in September, and he intends to apply for the permanent position. Donald Landry, a medical researcher and professor, came from Columbia University. This following perhaps the biggest presidential news this year with the June 3 rejection of University of Michigan President Santa Ono to take the helm at UF, the first such rejection in state history.
University of South Florida this month locked in former University of North Florida President Moez Limayem to lead after Rhea Law announced on Feb. 17 she was stepping down from the post, meaning UNF will kick off a search in the new year. 
Jeanette Nuñez stepped away from her role as Ron DeSantis’ lieutenant governor on Feb. 17 to become president at her alma mater, Florida International University.
That same week, former House GOP Leader Adam Hasner was approved as president of Florida Atlantic University after that school went two years under interim leadership.
University of West Florida began drawing the same treatment from the DeSantis administration that New College of Florida got a few years ago: a conservative makeover, tapping a former education commissioner to take the helm, and a controversial board of trustees.
Florida A&M University’s new president is politically connected, with experience serving in the administrations of Ron DeSantis as well as former Gov. Rick Scott. The FAMU community pushed back against Marva Johnson’s selection amid concerns that the search did not follow state law.
The Florida House this year approved making presidential searches public after the Legislature exempted them from public exposure in 2022. However, the Senate did not go along and DeSantis promised a veto if such a bill ever passes.
SUPPORT: YOU MAKE OUR WORK POSSIBLE
Lawsuits
Litigation over controversial laws during the past several years played out in court during 2025. 
Two major cases included the 2024 law banning social media use for younger children and restrictions for teenagers and another prohibiting courses involving diversity, equity, and inclusion for general education requirements for college undergraduates.
Lawmakers and the governor approved a law that requires parental consent for 14- and 15-year-olds to use social media platforms and bans it for kids 13 and younger. The law was a priority for Paul Renner, at the time speaker of the Florida House and now a candidate in the Republican gubernatorial primary.
Social media companies challenged it but were denied a preliminary injunction in March. In June, after redrafting their complaint, these companies were granted a temporary pause on enforcement.
In November, a federal appeals court voted 2-1 to allow the state to enforce its social media law. The state attorney general vowed his office “will aggressively enforce this law.”
In January, university professors challenged the state’s 2023 ban on diversity, equity, and inclusion spending in federal court.
Weeks later, the state university chancellor proclaimed that the system had eliminated “indoctrinating concepts” from the general education curriculum at Florida institutions. 
The case was heard for a preliminary injunction in March. In April, the judge ruled the state could enforce the ban while litigation plays out.
In September, the case was largely dismissed.
The state’s law purging of school books deemed “pornographic” or content that “describes sexual conduct” is before the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit after a federal trial judge in August ruled it “overbroad and unconstitutional.”
SUBSCRIBE: GET THE MORNING HEADLINES DELIVERED TO YOUR INBOX
Campus violence
In April, a gunman opened fire at the Florida State University student union, killing two people and wounding others. 
That prompted a reevaluation of campus safety as a group of students marched to the Capitol demanding change.
On Sept. 10, a shooter killed conservative activist Charlie Kirk in Utah. Subsequently in Florida, professors and teachers were punished over social media postings criticizing his politics. Additionally, the state of Florida has named a high school debate trophy after Kirk; New College plans to erect a statute of him on campus; and legislation has been introduced in the Legislature to designate Oct. 14 as a “Charlie Kirk Day of Remembrance” and directing colleges and universities to rename one street on campus after him.
A few days before the Kirk shooting, the Phoenix published results of the 2025 College Free Speech Rankings produced by the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression. Those rankings found 34% of students both nationwide and in Florida consider it acceptable, at least in rare cases, to use violence to stop a campus speech. In 2024, nationwide that number was 32%; in 2023, it was 27%; in 2022, it was 20%.
Kamoutsas and locals
With Diaz leaving for Pensacola, DeSantis elevated his aide Anastasios Kamoutsas to education commissioner on June 4. What followed was a new, or a more direct, culture of public threats against local school administrators on social media and in public attacks.
Education Commissioner Anastasios Kamoutsas (Photo via DOE)
Kamoutsas appeared at local school board meetings, including in Alachua and Leon counties, to criticize local officials over policy disagreements ranging from teacher salary negotiations to social media postings and has hauled county school board members in front of the state board on multiple occasions.
In September, one state board member said school district members were “clout chasing,” defying state board directives to elevate their public profiles.
The bad blood between state and local officials has escalated. Earlier this month, local officials booed Kamoutsas as he addressed a school board conference in Tampa, the Tampa Bay Times reported.
Kamoutsas opened a new X account when he became commissioner. Since, he has used the platform to issue a stream of threats to superintendents and local school board members, warning, “govern yourselves accordingly.”
New College and DOGE
Cost to produce a degree throughout a student’s span at the institution. (Screenshot via Board of Governors report)
Following Donald Trump’s reelection, his commitment to Department of Government Efficiency efforts leached down to the state level, with Florida promising to dive into state spending, including at universities.
In February, DeSantis promised to “prune” “ideological study stuff” at universities.
A November state report displayed each institution’s efficiency in spending tax dollars.
The results showed the per student costs at New College of Florida at nearly $500,000. As early as January, the Board of Governors had discussed whether New College was worth the spending.
The next closest in cost was Florida Polytechnic University, at about $154,000 to educate its mostly engineering students from start to finish.
The report found the University of Central Florida, with the largest enrollment, had the lowest cost to produce a degree from start to finish at $46,548.



Additional developments
DeSantis developing new university accreditor to ‘upend’ ‘woke accreditation cartels’
Federal assessments show reading and math performance drop in Florida, nation
Meet the state’s first public school chaplain, a politically active pastor
University of West Florida approves American Civic Republicanism Center
University of Florida commits to ‘neutrality,’ institutionally
Last-second bartering yielded two education omnibus bills

name: The Texas Tribune
title: Austin police officer Christopher Taylor acquitted in 2019 shooting by appeals court
description: Taylor's conviction was the first time a Travis County police officer had been found liable in an on-duty fatal shooting.
text: Christopher Taylor was acquitted in the 2019 fatal shooting of Mauris DeSilva, his lawyer announced late Tuesday.

name: Iowa Capital Dispatch
title: Democrats retain Iowa Senate seat in West Des Moines after special election
description: Renee Hardman, a West Des Moines council member and president and CEO of Lutheran Services in Iowa, won a special election Tuesday for Iowa Senate District 16, according to unofficial results.  Hardman’s win means Democrats retain the seat, formerly held by the late Sen. Claire Celsi, and they have stopped Republicans from potentially regaining a […]
text:
Iowans voted in a special election Dec. 30 for Iowa Senate District 16. (Photo by Cami Koons/Iowa Capital Dispatch)Renee Hardman, a West Des Moines council member and president and CEO of Lutheran Services in Iowa, won a special election Tuesday for Iowa Senate District 16, according to unofficial results. 
Hardman’s win means Democrats retain the seat, formerly held by the late Sen. Claire Celsi, and they have stopped Republicans from potentially regaining a supermajority in the Senate.
“Our community made their voices heard tonight,” Hardman said. “You braved the weather, you ignored the noise and the nonsense … I am ready to work as your next senator.”
SUBSCRIBE: GET THE MORNING HEADLINES DELIVERED TO YOUR INBOX
Hardman ran against Republican Lucas Loftin, who works for the forestry and environmental service company, Wright Service Corporation. Loftin and his wife are active in the homeschooling community.
Loftin, in a social media post Tuesday night said that while the results were not “what we wanted,” he would continue to have a smile on his face.
“We ran a good race, we are proud of the effort that we put in,” Loftin said.
Republicans lost their supermajority in the Senate after two earlier special elections, one in January after Lt. Gov. Chris Cournoyer joined Gov. Kim Reynolds’ administration and another after the death of Sen. Rocky De Witt, R-Lawton, in August. Democrats Sen. Mike Zimmer of DeWitt and Sen. Catelin Drey of Sioux City secured the seats.
Renee Hardman is running as a Democrat to represent Iowa Senate District 16. (Photo courtesy of Renee Hardman campaign)
With a supermajority, Republicans would have a two-thirds majority in the chamber without having to solicit a vote from a Democrat on matters like governor’s nominee confirmations.
Reynolds scheduled the Dec. 30 special election after the October death of Celsi, D-West Des Moines, who served as senator since 2018. The district comprises portions of Polk and Dallas counties, including parts of West Des Moines, Clive and Windsor Heights. 
Hardman formerly worked in administrative and human resources roles at Bankers Trust, Broadlawns Medical Center in Des Moines and Big Brothers Big Sisters of Central Iowa. 
Hardman was noted as a “spotlight candidate” for the Democratic Legislative Campaign Committee – a national Democrats’ campaign focused on state legislatures. 
The campaign’s president Heather Williams said in a statement that Democrats have been “on fire” with recent special election wins. In addition to the Iowa Senate Democrat wins, Rep. Angelina Ramirez, D-Cedar Rapids and Rep. Blaine Watkins, R-Donnellson, won special elections in the spring.
“Tonight, Iowans rebuked GOP chaos by blocking a toxic Republican supermajority, and made history by electing the first Black woman to serve in the Iowa Senate,” Williams said.
Iowa Democratic Party Chair Rita Hart congratulated Hardman in a statement Tuesday and said Hardman is “ready to step up to take on an even larger role” in the state.
“Renee Hardman crafted a well-run grassroots campaign focused on affordability, and Democrats across Iowa worked tirelessly to end 2025 with another 40-point victory to prevent a new Republican supermajority,” Hart said.
Unofficial results posted by the Iowa Secretary of State’s Office showed Hardman with 71.5% of the vote to 28.5% for Loftin with all of Polk County’s 23 precincts reporting. Dallas County had not reported results from its lone precinct as of 9 p.m.
SUPPORT: YOU MAKE OUR WORK POSSIBLE

name: Colorado Newsline
title: Former Colorado Sen. Ben Nighthorse Campbell dies at 92
description: Former U.S. Sen. Ben Nighthorse Campbell, who served two terms representing Colorado in the Senate beginning in 1993, died Tuesday at 92, according to media reports. Campbell was elected to the Senate as a Democrat, but in early 1995 switched to the Republican Party in a move that “startled and puzzled the political world,” The […]
text:
Former U.S. Sen. Ben Nighthorse Campbell (R-CO) speaks during the 21st Century Workforce Summit June 20, 2001 in Washington, DC. (Photo by Alex Wong/Getty Images)Former U.S. Sen. Ben Nighthorse Campbell, who served two terms representing Colorado in the Senate beginning in 1993, died Tuesday at 92, according to media reports.
Campbell was elected to the Senate as a Democrat, but in early 1995 switched to the Republican Party in a move that “startled and puzzled the political world,” The New York Times reported at the time. He was reelected in 1998 but declined to run for a third term in 2004, citing health concerns.
Born in California to a Portuguese mother and a father of Northern Cheyenne descent, Campbell was the fourth Native American elected to the U.S. Senate, and the first since the 1920s. He competed in judo at the 1964 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, and later became a well-known jewelry maker while making his home near Ignacio.
Prior to his election to the Senate, he had served two terms as a state lawmaker representing southwest Colorado, and three terms representing the 3rd District in the U.S. House.
U.S. Rep. Jeff Hurd, a Republican who currently represents the 3rd District, called Campbell “a towering figure in Colorado and American public life.”
“He devoted his life to service and was a respected national leader for Native American communities,” Hurd wrote in a social media post Tuesday. “His career was defined by independence, integrity, and service above partisanship.”
Campbell served as chair of the Senate Indian Affairs Committee until his retirement in 2005. During his House tenure, he sponsored legislation to establish the National Museum of the American Indian.
He later joined the firm Holland & Knight as a lobbyist. Lake Nighthorse, a reservoir near Durango constructed in 2003 as part of the Animas-La Plata Water Project, is named in his honor.
SUBSCRIBE: GET THE MORNING HEADLINES DELIVERED TO YOUR INBOX

name: Maryland Matters
title: Natural gas plant proposed for Harford County can get expedited review, commission says
description: The Public Service Commission gave an initial green light Tuesday to a Constellation Energy proposal for a new natural gas plant in Perryman, moving it to an expedited review approved last year by lawmakers anxious to boost in-state energy production.
text:
Constellation Energy CEO Joe Dominguez speaks Nov. 20 at the 2025 Policy Forum, where he provided details about his company's plans for potential new power generation projects proposed for Harford County. (Photo by Christine Condon/Maryland Matters)Constellation Energy’s proposals for a new natural gas power plant in Maryland can go through an expedited permitting process, after they received an initial green light from the Maryland Public Service Commission on Tuesday.
State lawmakers created the fast-track permitting process in the spring, in response to soaring energy bills, spurred in part by a lack of energy supply in the multistate electric grid that includes Maryland.
In response, Constellation submitted two possible proposals for a new natural gas power plant in the state — a larger and a smaller option. Both would be located in Harford County, near the existing Perryman power plant, which runs on oil and natural gas.
In a news release from November, Constellation said the proposals were meant to offer Maryland policymakers a “menu of options” for new power generation in the state. Constellation CEO Joe Dominguez said in the release that the company hopes to be a “thought partner” for state leaders as they decide the path forward.
“While there is a good deal of consensus on the need for battery storage, the future of natural gas in our state is less clear.” Dominguez said in the news release. “We believe that natural gas generation should be an option, but there are pros and cons to consider and, quite naturally, we do not want to build what our state does not want.”
During remarks at a Maryland Chamber of Commerce forum in November, Dominguez said that running pipelines to provide natural gas to the Perryman site could cost around $800 million, and said the company would likely need some form of state help to move forward with the costly plan.
After being ‘blindsided’ in 2025, advocates look to make climate part of the 2026 conversation

Tuesday’s PSC decision does not mean that either of Constellation’s new proposals will necessarily be built, only that they can go through the fast-track. Under the law, which took effect June 1, the commission has 295 days after the application is considered complete to make a final permit decision.
If constructed, though, a new natural gas plant would likely place many of Maryland’s climate emissions and clean energy aspirations out of reach. After talk of a new gas plant began circulating in the last legislative session, environmentalists pushed back hard, a fight that they expect to continue in the legislative session that begins Jan. 14. They also filed petitions directly to the commission opposing the Constellation gas proposals, and supporting battery storage.
In Tuesday’s order, PSC Executive Secretary Andrew S. Johnston wrote that the commission “is cognizant of and shares these concerns” regarding new fossil fuel-powered generation in Maryland. “However, the General Assembly has made a policy decision to expedite new generation construction, including natural gas-fired power plants under this process,” Johnston wrote.
Johnston added that environmental groups will have the opportunity to “raise concerns related to emissions and environmental justice” during the upcoming permitting process.
Constellation also submitted a proposal for an 800-gigawatt battery energy storage project for expedited review, but the PSC denied it, saying it did not meet all of the qualifications set by the legislature. Lawmakers set up the fast-track for so-called “dispatchable” energy generation, which is easy to deploy during times of peak demand.
The battery proposal, proposed for several spots on the Perryman site, fell just below a reliability threshold set by lawmakers, according to the commission, which denied the project “despite the other good characteristics” it possessed. Lawmakers did, however, create a separate approval process for battery storage projects in the legislation they passed this year.
Two other companies submitted fast-track proposals, but both were withdrawn before the commission issued its decision.
One proposal would have upgraded an existing natural gas power plant in Prince George’s County’s Brandywine, and the other was entirely confidential, much to the chagrin of environmental groups. The Brandywine proposal also received blowback, from local activists who argued that the area is already overburdened by power plants and industrial facilities.
SUPPORT: YOU MAKE OUR WORK POSSIBLE
In a news release issued earlier this month, a group of Perryman residents and members of the community group 3P Protect Perryman Peninsula expressed concerns about a possible new gas plant in their community. They also pushed for the PSC to take more time to review the energy proposals before deciding which could move through the fast-track.
“They’re asking regulators to move first and ask questions later,” said Stacy Stone, a lifelong Perryman resident who lives near the proposed site and serves on the Harford County Democratic Central Committee. “Maryland strengthened its environmental justice laws because communities like ours were harmed when decisions were rushed. Those protections don’t work if they’re treated as an afterthought.”
But the commission denied a request for a 60-day extension, originally filed by several other environmental groups: the Maryland League of Conservation Voters, Clean Water Action, Earthjustice and the Maryland chapter of the Sierra Club.
In the order, Johnston wrote that the “short timeline” reflects “the General Assembly’s urgency in responding to the lack of new generation in Maryland.”
“The General Assembly understood that the timeline it proposed would limit stakeholder participation in the initial review of proposals,” Johnston added.

name: Daily Montanan
title: Realtor says Missoula organization should have backed LGBTQ+ professionals, clients
description: When Karen Berg-DiGangi first became licensed as a Realtor in Missoula, other queer real estate agents told her it was better not to be “out” or open about her LGBTQ+ identity. “I like to tell my clients that was my villain origin story because I took that as a challenge,” Berg-DiGangi said. “I feel like […]
text:
Realtor Karen Berg-DiGangi pushed the Missoula Organization of Realtors to sponsor Missoula Pride. (Provided by DiGangi)When Karen Berg-DiGangi first became licensed as a Realtor in Missoula, other queer real estate agents told her it was better not to be “out” or open about her LGBTQ+ identity.
“I like to tell my clients that was my villain origin story because I took that as a challenge,” Berg-DiGangi said. “I feel like we are in a place where I should be able to post about my family just as much as any other Realtor should be able to post about their family and be super open and affirming.”
Berg-DiGangi filed one of the ethics complaints against Brandon Huber, a pastor and Realtor who recently announced he reached a settlement in a discrimination and religious liberty case taken up with the Missoula Organization of Realtors and National Association of Realtors.
In a recent interview, Berg-DiGangi said the public should know about her less publicized complaint against Huber — the allegations that originally led to sanctions — and the aftermath.
She said people who are queer still face challenges in real estate, but a recent change the national association made to its code and decision the local organization made to abandon its earlier stance on the Huber case undercuts support for the LGBTQ+ community.
“I feel betrayed and disappointed by both the Missoula Organization of Realtors and the National Association of Realtors,” Berg-DiGangi said. “I was told they made the best decision for the corporation.”
One case settled, ethics code changed
In 2021, Huber, then a pastor of the Clinton Community Church, cut off church ties with the Missoula Food Bank and Community Center because of its support for the LGBTQ+ community, an announcement that led to an initial complaint.
A community member who was not a client of Huber’s filed a discrimination complaint alleging his actions violated the ethics code of the National Association of Realtors, enforced by the Missoula Organization of Realtors.
At the time, the code of ethics and standards of practice said Realtors “must not use harassing speech, hate speech, epithets, or slurs based on race, color, religion, sex, handicap, familial status, national origin, sexual orientation or gender identity.” It said the code applied to Realtors “in all their activities,” not just real estate activities.










I feel betrayed and disappointed by both the Missoula Organization of Realtors and the National Association of Realtors.


– Karen Berg-DiGangi


While a hearing panel with the Missoula Organization of Realtors cleared Huber of the complaint related to the food bank, the panel found a separate social media post by Huber had violated the ethics code.
In a demand letter this summer, Huber and a national legal firm, Liberty Counsel, alleged religious discrimination, and they announced this month the case had been settled. The agreement wiped out sanctions against Huber levied by the local Realtors and funds his local and national license fees through 2027.
The local Realtors conceded to Huber after Liberty Counsel, a national Christian organization that defends religious freedom and the First Amendment, threatened to file a complaint of religious bias against the Missoula Organization of Realtors with the U.S. Department of Justice.
Two complaints, two circumstances
In the first complaint, Huber was accused of “hate speech” after he made the decision his church would disassociate with the food bank because of its support for LGBTQ+ people.
His lawyer said his statements about that decision weren’t hateful by any stretch — and Berg-DiGangi said she agrees with the hearing panel’s decision to clear Huber of the allegation.
Berg-DiGangi summed up the comments Huber made as — “we’re not interested in this partnership anymore” — not “hateful” as alleged, and she said most Realtors with whom she discussed the case agreed.
Karen DiGangi has been a Realtor since 2020. (Provided by DiGangi)
However, Berg-DiGangi said the complaint she filed — the one a hearing panel of the Missoula Organization of Realtors found to be valid — was based on different circumstances. And she said it is based on a standard to which she believes the Realtors should have held firm.
In her complaint, Berg-DiGangi pointed to a social media post Huber had made on both his personal and pastor Facebook pages of a flyer that invited people to a rally where “Pastor JD Hall” would “expose the LGBTQ agenda that controls our lives and kills our liberty.”
(Hall was a pastor based in Sidney who ran into legal trouble and filed for bankruptcy protection in 2022 after a publication he owned posted untrue stories about a transgender woman. As part of a settlement, Hall admitted the information he published was false. He was also removed from church membership.)
Huber said he was a guest speaker at the event, and he shared the flyer, but the words on the flyer were from Hall: “Those words never came out of my mouth.” A letter from Liberty Counsel said that flyer “did not demean any individual or any group,” but it highlighted a discussion about “Cancel Culture and censorship on free speech.”
In her complaint, however, Berg-DiGangi said the language has implications for real estate.
“This harassing and hateful language makes me feel both as an LGBTQ+ individual and as a Realtor that I, or my clients, would not be welcome to do business with Brandon,” Berg-DiGangi wrote in the complaint.
In 2022, the Missoula Organization of Realtors found that complaint to be valid; it ordered Huber to pay a $5,000 fine and take a fair housing class, both sanctions with which Huber refused to comply.
Huber had argued in part that the ethics code violated the Montana Constitution’s protection of civil expression, and Liberty Counsel argued unlawful religious discrimination.
In spring 2025, the national Board of Directors decided the prohibition on harassment in its policy should have a more narrow application, only to a Realtor acting within their business capacity.
An explanation on the National Association of Realtors website said the changes “are intended to reduce risk to state and local associations.”
In June 2025, Huber told the local Realtors they needed to reconsider sanctions based on changes to the national code, but the local Realtors said the changes didn’t nullify previous outcomes under previous code, according to the Liberty Counsel demand letter.
Berg-DiGangi believes that’s where the argument should have ended. She said Realtors must “sign on the dotted line” that they agree to follow a code of ethics, but Huber ignored those professional standards.
After Huber and the Liberty Counsel threatened legal action, the local Realtors lifted sanctions against him.
Berg-DiGangi said recent changes the National Association of Realtors made to its ethics code leave members of the public and LGBTQ+ people vulnerable, and she wishes the Missoula Organization of Realtors hadn’t buckled under threat.
She said the local Realtors caved, first stating they would not review former cases, and then not only lifting sanctions from those penalties, but funding license fees for Huber. She said the Missoula Organization of Realtors told her it had acted “for the betterment of the corporation.”
“Why would you reward someone who doesn’t believe in your process? Who doesn’t follow our code of conduct or our code of ethics?” Berg-DiGangi said.
Missoula Organization of Realtors’ Jim Bachand did not answer a question about why the organization reversed course in Huber’s complaint after initially stating it would not nullify previous outcomes under previous code.
“Since the conduct of Mr. Huber that was the subject of the 2022 ethics hearing was not engaged by Mr. Huber in his capacity of a real estate professional, due to NAR’s adoption of the June 2025 change to Professional Standards Policy Statement 29, MOR decided to rescind all discipline imposed against Mr. Huber,” he said.
He declined to comment on whether the Department of Justice had been involved directly with the local Realtors.
Bachand said the local Realtors do not comment on results of ethics complaints or hearings, which are confidential, but he confirmed the Missoula Organization of Realtors rescinded the discipline imposed on Huber in 2022.
“As a voluntary trade association, MOR applies ethical standards through established Professional Standards processes while also exercising its fiduciary responsibility to act in the best interests of the organization and its membership as a whole,” Bachand wrote.
Policy changes, then and now
Berg-DiGangi said she believes professionals in her industry who want to be Realtors, that is, official members of the professional association, should hold themselves to a high ethical standard in not only their professional lives, but in their personal lives.
The current code says Realtors can’t harass anyone based on who they are “in their capacity as real estate professionals, in association with their real estate businesses, or in their real estate-related activities.”
She said it’s likely some Christian Realtors have similar feelings to Huber but still aren’t publicly accusing LGBTQ+ people of “killing liberties,” and the recent change in the code of ethics diminishes its role.
As a result, she said, the public loses. She said she fears people might not even want to report a Realtor they believe has acted inappropriately under the new code.
“I understand why they’d be scared to say something now, and that’s not fair,” Berg-DiGangi said.
She also said the policy was instated in 2020 for a reason — after a Newsday investigation found “consistent discrimination” against people of color at brokerage firms on Long Island. In part, the investigation found Black buyers were treated differently than white buyers 49% of the time.
“I believe that you cannot, for lack of a better phrase, take off your white hood and then go sell real estate and claim to be unbiased,” Berg-DiGangi said.
Advocacy going forward
In the business since 2020, Berg-DiGangi loves her profession, helping people with one of the biggest decisions of their lives, if not the biggest one.
“Especially as a millennial, in my 30s, it feels like it is hardest for my generation,” Berg-DiGangi said. “And feeling like I can help guide them through that and still make it attainable for my peers has been really rewarding.”
She helped encourage the Missoula Organization of Realtors to sponsor Missoula Pride (she said one board member resigned immediately after the decision). She’s also working on forming a state or local chapter of the LGBTQ+ Real Estate Alliance.
Berg-DiGangi said LGBTQ+ home ownership is roughly 16% below the national average, and queer real estate clients face hurdles. For example, clients often ask if a seller can see names on real estate documents, and if they’ll be subject to discrimination if documents show two traditionally female names as buyers, for instance.
“The seller can see the names, but if they are working with a member of the National Association of Realtors — a Realtor — their Realtor should be describing fair housing to them and ensuring that the seller is not violating fair housing,” Berg-DiGangi said.
She also worked with a client who was a veteran whose Veterans Affairs benefits were in their “dead name,” a name they no longer used after they transitioned. Berg-DiGangi said it’s a team process, working with title companies, home inspectors and lenders who understand how to navigate some of the issues.
A couple of years ago, she said, the national LGBTQ+ Real Estate Alliance, of which she is a founding member, brought to Missoula an instructor for a certified ally class to teach some of the struggles LGBTQ+ homeowners face. She said Realtors had to pay for the course, and it was well attended.
Now, Berg-DiGangi is stepping down from the Missoula Organization of Realtors committee work where she has advocated for LGBTQ+ home owners and Realtors. In the wake of its decision to reverse course in the complaint she filed, she doesn’t believe the organization merits her leadership.
(She said the decision not only wiped away penalties, it rewarded Huber by waiving his real estate dues. In the meantime, she said, she had to pay legal fees for representation: “Where’s my $4,000 legal fee refund?”)
But Berg-DiGangi said she’ll keep working on opening the local chapter of the LGBTQ+ Real Estate Alliance, and she’ll continue to stand on her principles in a public way, despite the earlier guidance she should hide.
“The reality is, more people choose me because of how I present in the community than anything else, and that is both for queer or heterosexual couples,” Berg-DiGangi said. “I find that people feel that they know my values off the bat, and therefore don’t have questions of who I am and the kind of business that I do.”

name: Maryland Matters
title: Federal judge orders release of some records for Abrego Garcia’s vindictive prosecution claim
description: A federal judge in Tennessee is ordering federal prosecutors to turn over some documents to lawyers for Kilmar Abrego Garcia as they try to show his indictment on human smuggling charges was the product of vindictive prosecution.
text:
Kilmar Abrego Garcia stands outside U.S. District Court in Greenbelt with his wife, Jennifer Vasquez Sura, left, and Lydia Walther-Rodriguez with CASA, after a federal judge ruled earlier this month he was allowed to remain free. (File photo by William J. Ford/Maryland Matters)A federal judge in Tennessee is ordering federal prosecutors to turn over some documents to lawyers for Kilmar Abrego Garcia as they try to show his indictment on human smuggling charges was the product of vindictive prosecution.
U.S. District Judge Waverly Crenshaw’s nine-page ruling — issued under seal Dec. 3, but unsealed at noon Tuesday in U.S. District Court in Nashville — said a “subset” of more than 3,000 government documents he reviewed appear to undercut the government’s defense against vindictive prosecution.
“Specifically, the government’s documents may contradict its prior representations that the decision to prosecute was made locally and that there were no outside influences,” Crenshaw wrote.
The order is a partial victory for Abrego Garcia, the Salvadoran native who lives in Maryland, where he was stopped by immigration agents in March and deported to a notorious prison in El Salvador. His removal came without due process and despite an earlier court order that prohibited  immigration officials from deporting Abrego Garcia to his home country, for fear of violence.
A series of court battles ended with the U.S. Supreme Court in April ordering Abrego Garcia be returned to the United States. He was finally brought back to the U.S. in June, where he faced new charges of human smuggling, stemming from a 2022 traffic stop in Tennessee where he was let go without a citation.
Abrego Garcia argues that the smuggling charge was concocted years after the fact to punish him for embarrassing the administration in court, and should be thrown out.
Kilmar Abrego Garcia can remain a free man for the holidays, judge rules

The charges of “conspiracy to unlawfully transport illegal aliens for financial gain” and “unlawful transportation of illegal aliens for financial gain” are tied to a 2022 traffic stop in Putnam County, Tennessee, where he was pulled over for speeding. There were nine passengers in the back of his car.
Abrego Garcia was not arrested. No ticket was issued.
But three years later, as he was winning his case to be returned to the U.S., federal prosecutors were revisiting that traffic stop. A Homeland Security agent told a federal judge earlier this year that he was told on April 28 of this year to investigate the traffic stop.
Abrego Garcia pleaded not guilty to the charges, that his attorneys have claimed were filed as retaliation against their client. They claim senior officials in the Justice Department pushed for the indictment, citing television interviews where Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche said the investigation began after “a judge in Maryland … questioned” the government and accused it of “doing something wrong,” according to Crenshaw’s order.
The government denies involvement by higher-ups, saying the decision to prosecute Abrego Garcia was made solely by Robert McGuire, the U.S. Attorney for the Middle District of Tennessee.
Crenshaw’s order includes a timeline of events. In it are several communications between McGuire and D.C.-based U.S. Associate Deputy Attorney General Aakash Singh that began on April 27, one day before a federal agent was assigned to investigate the 2022 traffic stop.
In an April 30 exchange, Singh writes that Abrego’s case is “a top priority.” McGuire writes “we want the high command looped in.”
In a May 15 email, McGuire writes about the pending indictment.
“Ultimately, I would hope to have ODAG [Office of the Deputy Attorney General] eyes on it as we move towards a decision about whether this matter is going to ultimately be charged,” he wrote, according to Crenshaw’s order.
McGuire adds: “While ultimately, the office’s decision to charge will land on me. I think it makes sense to get the benefit of all of your brains and talent in this process and as we consider this case. I have not received specific direction from ODAG other than I have heard anecdotally that the DAG and PDAG would like Garcia charged sooner rather than later.”
SUPPORT: YOU MAKE OUR WORK POSSIBLE
Singh is updated about the indictment over the next week, according to Crenshaw’s timeline.
“These documents show that McGuire did not act alone and to the extent McGuire had input on the decision to prosecute, he shared it with Singh and others,” Crenshaw wrote.
Abrego’s attorneys successfully made a case before Crenshaw that prosecutors had acted vindictively. They sought the release of documents through discovery. Federal prosecutors balked and withheld those documents, citing privilege.
Crenshaw, in his now-unsealed order, said allowing the privilege assertion to trump due process protections would undermine rulings by other federal courts.
“The Court recognizes the government’s assertion of privileges, but Abrego’s due process right to a non-vindictive prosecution outweighs the blanket evidentiary privileges asserted by the government,” Crenshaw wrote. “If the work product, attorney-client, and deliberative process privileges asserted by the government precluded all discovery in the context of a vindictiveness motion, defendants would never be able to answer the question ‘what motivated the government’s prosecution?'”

name: Nebraska Examiner
title: NU Regent O’Connor resigning, effective Jan. 9, in wake of DUI allegation, possible impeachment
description: LINCOLN — Embattled University of Nebraska Regent Elizabeth O’Connor, who increasingly faced likely impeachment proceedings, announced Tuesday that she is resigning her post. O’Connor, 35, faces a felony charge of drunken driving causing bodily injury from a Douglas County crash that police say totaled two vehicles and broke the back and pelvis of a passenge[...]
text:
University of Nebraska Regent Elizabeth O'Connor of Omaha speaks in Lincoln at the NU Board of Regents. Dec. 5, 2025. (Zach Wendling/Nebraska Examiner)LINCOLN — Embattled University of Nebraska Regent Elizabeth O’Connor, who increasingly faced likely impeachment proceedings, announced Tuesday that she is resigning her post.
O’Connor, 35, faces a felony charge of drunken driving causing bodily injury from a Douglas County crash that police say totaled two vehicles and broke the back and pelvis of a passenger.
Authorities allege the Omaha-area regent and former student regent tested with a blood alcohol content of 0.321% after the May 21 crash in the Benson area, in her eastern Douglas County district. That’s four times the legal limit.
The father of three young children injured in the crash had lobbied the NU regent to resign and called on lawmakers and other politicians to ramp up the pressure on O’Connor to resign.
State Sen. Kathleen Kauth of the Millard area. Oct. 30, 2025. (Zach Wendling/Nebraska Examiner)
State Sen. Kathleen Kauth of Omaha, a Republican in the officially nonpartisan Legislature, had pledged to pursue impeachment if O’Connor, a Democrat, didn’t resign. Impeaching her would require at least 25 votes and the approval of her removal by the Nebraska Supreme Court. The Nebraska Legislature last impeached a state official in 2006, then-NU Regent C. David Hergert.
O’Connor, who has served as an elected member of the NU board since 2019, said in a statement that she did not want to “become a distraction to the Board’s important work.”
“I am choosing to resign now because I want to do the right thing for our great university,” she said in a statement. 
“The University of Nebraska is facing many important opportunities and challenges, and District Four must have a representative that can serve effectively on the Board.”
Kauth, a Republican, said O’Connor should have resigned immediately as she still had seven months’ worth of decisions at the university, including managing a $3.6 billion budget.
“Clearly, she does not make great decisions, so I question why she stayed in so long,” Kauth said Tuesday. 
Kauth’s push to consider O’Connor’s possible removal appeared to have significant bipartisan support, based on a recent survey of lawmakers by the Nebraska Examiner, which had been preparing a story on the topic. The Legislature currently consists of 33 Republicans, 15 Democrats and one nonpartisan progressive.
Any Democratic support for impeachment would likely imperil her ability to continue to serve. Three Democrats had said by mid-December that they would vote to impeach, and a fourth signaled leaning toward supporting impeachment.
State Sen. Dave Murman of Glenvil, chair of the Legislature’s Education Committee and a Republican, said he was “definitely” in favor of impeaching O’Connor and that she should have resigned “a long time ago.” He noted public video evidence of the alleged crash.
“Regents, like it or not, should be a model for student behavior, and with that serious of a felony allegation and the overwhelming evidence of what happened, she should do the right thing and resign,” Murman said Dec. 18. “If she doesn’t, I think she should be impeached.
SUPPORT: YOU MAKE OUR WORK POSSIBLE
State Sens. Merv Riepe of Ralston, a Republican, and Jane Raybould of Lincoln, a Democrat, questioned why the regents had not weighed in first on O’Connor’s fate. Under the Nebraska Constitution, only the Legislature can impeach a constitutional officer.
Gov. Jim Pillen, who had served with O’Connor for four years on the regents, also had weighed in early September, suggesting that she should resign if the allegations were true. His office had no immediate comment Tuesday on the resignation announcement.
The governor, a Republican from Columbus, would appoint her replacement, which would likely add a conservative member from one of the state’s most Democratic-leaning districts until a special election in November 2026 to serve the remainder of O’Connor’s term through the end of 2030. She was reelected in 2024 with 67% of the vote.
In O’Connor’s statement, the first to address her elected position since the charges were brought in July, she credited the work of her fellow board members and NU faculty and staff. Her resignation is effective at 11:59 p.m. Jan. 9, she and NU officials separately confirmed.
“The University of Nebraska is a very special place, and it represents the unique culture and leadership that is evident in the daily lives of Nebraskans in every community across our great state,” she said.
University of Nebraska President Jeffrey Gold. Nov. 7, 2025. (Zach Wendling/Nebraska Examiner)
NU President Dr. Jeffrey Gold, in a statement of his own Tuesday afternoon, thanked O’Connor for her service and said he and NU “look forward to working with her successor to further advance and strengthen our university.”
Kauth said O’Connor should have recognized sooner that her continued service would be a “distraction,” not a week before the 2026 legislative session begins. Kauth reiterated she would have formally begun impeachment on Day One. She had briefed a legislative committee on the process in October. Half of the committee told the Examiner they supported impeachment.
“Had we not had articles of impeachment drawn up and ready to go, would she have even thought to resign?” Kauth asked.
Charges against O’Connor were brought July 30, two months after the crash. The delay came as prosecutors awaited O’Connor’s blood test from the lab, and because the Douglas County Attorney’s Office transferred the case to the Omaha City Prosecutor’s Office to avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest to avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest. 
Until early August, O’Connor served as a deputy county attorney. 
Part of the 2026 legislative session will include plugging a projected $471 million budget deficit for the state through mid-2027. NU campus leaders have already taken steps to cut more than $40 million from NU’s systemwide budget this fall, and some lawmakers noted O’Connor’s service wouldn’t help the university system, one of the state’s largest line items in the budget.
“If the university is not living up to the standards that we think the university should, and that includes the regents, it doesn’t help,” Murman said.
Kauth said she had the 24 other votes necessary to impeach.
“No matter when that elected official chooses to misbehave and do something that deserves impeachment, we have to address it,” Kauth said. “The fact that she finally resigned means we are able to look at other issues, and we’re going to have a lot this session.”
O’Connor is next scheduled in Douglas County District Court Jan. 22. Her case appears headed to trial as her defense is subpoenaing medical records and conducting depositions.
