name: Michigan Advance
title: Top Michigan Advance stories of 2025
description: As a Michigan Republican made his case to ban same-sex marriage, a gay Democrat stole the show   At a Lansing news conference meant to push a resolution urging the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn marriage equality, a Michigan Republican instead found himself eclipsed. As Rep. Josh Schriver (R-Oxford) argued for banning same-sex marriage, Sen. […]
text:
Graphic by Susan DemasAs a Michigan Republican made his case to ban same-sex marriage, a gay Democrat stole the show

 
At a Lansing news conference meant to push a resolution urging the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn marriage equality, a Michigan Republican instead found himself eclipsed. As Rep. Josh Schriver (R-Oxford) argued for banning same-sex marriage, Sen. Jeremy Moss (D-Bloomfield) — the state’s first openly gay senator — seized the moment, delivering a sharp, personal defense of LGBTQ+ families and the rights they’ve held for a decade. With GOP leaders distancing themselves from the proposal, Moss’s impromptu response stole the spotlight, turning an effort to roll back rights into a vivid reminder of how firmly marriage equality is now defended in Michigan.
 
 
Michigan State Police: Ted Nugent was armed during Capitol visit due to security breakdown

 
At a Michigan Capitol hearing where rockstar and conservative firebrand Ted Nugent was testifying against state conservation policies, a major security lapse stole headlines: Nugent walked into the building armed, despite a ban on open and concealed carry on Capitol grounds. Michigan State Police later confirmed that although the weapons detection system correctly flagged a possible weapon, the trooper at the checkpoint didn’t notice the alert until after Nugent had already entered and given his testimony — prompting an internal review of screening procedures. While officers later located Nugent and made sure he was no longer armed inside the Capitol, the incident raised fresh concerns about enforcement of safety policies in Michigan’s Capitol complex.
 
 
Michigan legislator says she underwent sterilization to avoid pregnancy during Trump presidency

 
Michigan state Rep. Laurie Pohutsky (D-Livonia) made national headlines when she revealed at a protest outside the State Capitol that she had voluntarily undergone sterilization — a deeply personal decision she said was driven by fear of losing access to contraception and reproductive health care under President Donald Trump’s administration. Speaking to hundreds gathered as part of a nationwide “50501 Movement,” Pohutsky said she chose the permanent procedure to avoid ever having to navigate a pregnancy in what she called “Donald Trump’s America,” arguing that her body should not be treated as “currency” by a government she believes threatens reproductive rights. Her candid disclosure sparked widespread discussion about reproductive freedom, political fear and the lengths some are taking to protect their autonomy.
 
 
In a blow to Democrats’ chances to retake the US Senate, Peters declines to seek reelection in 2026

 
In a surprise political shake-up that reshaped Michigan’s role in the 2026 midterms, U.S. Sen. Gary Peters (D-Bloomfield Township) announced he would not seek reelection, leaving a crucial battleground Senate seat open and Democrats scrambling to defend it in a year when Republicans are poised to hold onto a slim majority. Peters’ retirement — following longtime Sen. Debbie Stabenow’s exit in 2024 — instantly turned the upcoming race into one of the most competitive in the country, with the fight for Michigan’s U.S. Senate spot becoming a high-stakes chapter in the battle for control of Congress.
 
 
A Black man says officials in Howell, Michigan, targeted him after he confronted white supremacists

 
In Howell, Michigan — a small mid-Michigan city struggling with a long-standing reputation tied to white supremacy — Black resident Jeff Amayo confronted white supremacists outside a community event, prompting city officials to publicly label his actions as provocative while downplaying the extremist demonstrators. Amayo went on to file a complaint with the Michigan Department of Civil Rights accusing municipal leaders and police of targeting him instead of addressing racial harassment. His dispute highlighted deep tensions over how Howell responds to hate groups, local activism and the safety of its most vulnerable residents, raising questions about priorities as the city worked to repair its image.
 
 
Michigan budget crisis averted: Legislature, Whitmer announce deal days before shutdown

 
In late September, with Michigan’s Oct. 1 fiscal deadline looming and state government on the brink of a shutdown, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer and legislative leaders struck a last-minute budget compromise that kept the lights on at the Capitol and state services running. Facing intense negotiations over revenue, spending priorities and how to fund roads, schools and essential programs, lawmakers and the governor announced a deal just days before a shutdown could have halted operations — marking a framework that set the stage for final votes on a full 2025–26 spending plan and underscoring the high stakes of timely budget negotiations for the state’s residents and institutions.
 
 
Bernie Sanders draws 10,000 supporters to Warren for a ‘Fight Oligarchy’ rally

 
Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vermont) packed Lincoln High School in Warren and its overflow rooms with more than 10,000 people on March 8 as part of his national “Fighting Oligarchy: Where We Go From Here” tour, drawing one of the biggest progressive rallies in Michigan in years. Sanders used the event to warn against what he called rising oligarchic and authoritarian forces in U.S. politics, urging attendees to stand up against concentrated wealth and political influence while connecting historical movements for justice to the challenges of today. The rally became a vivid showcase of energy, resistance and calls for economic and political reform as the 2026 election cycle begins to take shape.
 
 
University of Michigan Health ends gender-affirming care after DOJ subpoena

 
In a controversial decision that reverberated across the state, University of Michigan Health announced it would stop providing medically necessary gender-affirming care for minors after receiving a subpoena from the U.S. Department of Justice as part of a federal investigation into such treatments, a move that advocates say capitulates to political pressure and leaves transgender youth with fewer options for critical care. The hospital system — part of Michigan’s largest academic medical network — cited escalating legal risks in halting puberty blockers and hormone therapy for patients under 19, even as major medical organizations continue to recognize such care as evidence-based and lifesaving. Equality Michigan and others condemned the choice as harmful and chilling, while state leaders reiterated that gender-affirming care remains legal in Michigan and vowed to defend patients’ rights amid broader national scrutiny of transgender health services.
 
 
Whitmer signs Republican-led push for Michigan earmark reforms into law

 
In a rare moment of bipartisan cooperation following a bruising budget battle, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer signed a pair of Republican‑led earmark reform bills into law, marking a significant shift in how Michigan handles legislatively directed spending. The new laws require state lawmakers to disclose earmarks publicly early in the budget process — including who sponsored them and why — instead of hiding them until the final budget vote, giving the public and press weeks to scrutinize these funding requests. Championed by House Speaker Matt Hall (R-Richland Township) and negotiated into the deal that ended a brief government shutdown, the reforms aim to inject transparency and accountability into Lansing’s budget process and curb “pork barrel” spending that critics contend too often occurs behind closed doors.
 
 
In Michigan, Vance makes a proposal to Whitmer: Sending National Guard troops to Detroit

 
During a visit to Howell in mid‑September, Vice President JD Vance made headlines by publicly offering to send National Guard troops into Detroit to help address crime — if Gov. Gretchen Whitmer simply asked for them, thrusting the controversial idea of federal military involvement in a major U.S. city back into the spotlight. Vance’s remarks — delivered at a rally originally focused on economic policy — underscored sharp political divisions over public safety, with Republicans framing the proposal as support for law‑and‑order and critics warning it could mean militarizing Detroit. While the Trump administration touted similar deployments elsewhere, local leaders and Whitmer herself have pushed back against the plan, arguing that existing partnerships and community‑based strategies are more effective than sending in troops.

name: South Dakota Searchlight
title: South Dakota Searchlight’s most-viewed commentary of 2025
description: The “reset” pursued by former South Dakota Gov. Kristi Noem’s successor, Larry Rhoden, was the topic of the most-viewed commentary on South Dakota Searchlight’s website in 2025. Other top-viewed commentaries this year addressed various Noem controversies; land and conservation issues involving farmers, the Black Hills, logging and wetlands; a new book about[...]
text:
Popular commentary topics in 2025 included, clockwise from top left, wetlands, departing Gov. Kristi Noem and her successor Larry Rhoden, the Black Hills, and teachers. (Top left photo by John Deuter/USDA NRCS South Dakota, public license, top right photo by David Bordewyk/South Dakota News Media Association, bottom photos by South Dakota Searchlight)The “reset” pursued by former South Dakota Gov. Kristi Noem’s successor, Larry Rhoden, was the topic of the most-viewed commentary on South Dakota Searchlight’s website in 2025.
Other top-viewed commentaries this year addressed various Noem controversies; land and conservation issues involving farmers, the Black Hills, logging and wetlands; a new book about weather in the “Little House on the Prairie” series; and teacher shortages.
Scroll down to see Searchlight’s 10 most-viewed pieces of commentary published in 2025.

Noem’s successor hits ‘reset’ after she insisted there was ‘No Going Back’

‘Big, beautiful’ funding for Trump statue garden could put an ugly blemish in the Black Hills

Funding freezes and staff cuts pull the rug out from under farmers

In ‘Little House’ books and life, the plow followed the rain

Can South Dakota afford to keep Kristi Noem on its payroll?

South Dakota stands to lose its life-giving waters

Noem’s public broadcasting cut proves she’s nothing like Mr. Rogers and a lot like Trump

Politicians can demand more logging in the Black Hills, but they can’t make trees grow faster

Noem’s attempt to ‘prioritize education’ gets failing grade

It’s not hard to figure out why young South Dakotans don’t want to be teachers

name: New Jersey Monitor
title: Abortions in New Jersey rose steadily after Supreme Court ruling
description: Abortions have spiked since the 2022 Dobbs decision, with a half million reported nationally, including 30,540 in NJ, the first half of 2025.
text:
Abortion rights advocates rally outside the Statehouse in Trenton on Sept. 29, 2022. (Photo by Dana DiFiliippo / New Jersey Monitor)The number of abortions in New Jersey has steadily climbed since the U.S. Supreme Court struck down the federal right to abortion in 2022, a new report has found.
New Jersey’s abortion providers performed 4,920 abortions in June, up 21% from 4,060 in June 2022, when the nation’s top court overturned Roe v. Wade in a decision known as Dobbs, according to a Society of Family Planning report released earlier this month.
Clinicians in the Garden State provided 30,540 abortions during the first half of this year, and 57,510 abortions last year, up 8% from 53,290 in 2023, the report shows.
Since Dobbs, New Jersey lawmakers have codified abortion rights and enacted other protections for both patients and providers, including passing a shield law to prevent states that ban or restrict the procedure from holding out-of-state patients and their New Jersey-based providers criminally or civilly liable for abortions.
(Chart courtesy of Society of Family Planning)
New Jersey’s uptick in abortions has mirrored a trend in other states that have protected access to the procedure, as well as an overall national surge in abortions. There were 99,000 abortions on average per month across the country (totaling 591,770) for the first half of this year, compared to 80,000 a month in 2022, data shows.
Most abortions in New Jersey still take place in person, with about 12% provided through telehealth as of June.
That’s down from the national telehealth average of 27%, a figure inflated by states that ban abortion.  Where abortion is banned, almost all abortions were provided under shield laws via telehealth, researchers reported. Just 5% of abortions were provided via telehealth in spring 2022, data shows.
Kaitlyn Wojtowicz, executive director of the Planned Parenthood Action Fund of New Jersey, attributed the rising abortion numbers in New Jersey at least in part to out-of-state patients coming here. Planned Parenthood has 19 health centers in the Garden State.
“Since the overturning of Roe v. Wade, abortion providers in New Jersey have stepped up to provide care to thousands of patients who are forced to leave their home states in search of abortion care,” Wojtowicz said. “These patients, coming from states like Texas, Florida, and Georgia, must travel hundreds of miles to access the care they need.”
Marie Tasy, who heads New Jersey Right to Life, had a different take. She said abortion is rising here because “the state keeps pouring hundreds of millions of taxpayer money into providers that perform abortions, while targeting pregnancy-resource centers that offer women real choices.”
A coalition of pregnancy centers has been fighting the state since Attorney General Matt Platkin issued a consumer alert in December 2022 claiming that some centers masquerade as abortion providers in an effort to discourage visitors from seeking abortion. The fight went all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court earlier this month.
The surge in abortions here “are a tragic reminder that our policies aren’t just wrong — they’re perverse. It’s a number to be mourned, not celebrated,” Tasy said.
“This administration and its party bosses have clearly failed women,” she added.
